Now it is time to kick off your discussion with a question. Which question will you ask Dr. Cardonza first?</welcomeText>

choice.choiceText: A. During my previous talks with Dr. Gomez, we’ve discussed therapy and treatment options for hyponatremia. Can you tell me more about the opportunities for treating hyponatremia that you see?
B. With the ongoing healthcare reform and increasing regulations, what issues do you see potentially affecting your department?
C. It sounds like maintaining your department’s reputation is one of your top priorities. What are your next steps to address that priority?

D. From previous conversations with Dr. Gomez, I’ve learned that you want to continue building your department’s reputation and stay at the forefront of medical advances. As part of achieving those goals, what are the treatment goals you desire for your patients with hyponatremia?

This is an Options question, not a Results question. It focuses too narrowly on a single issue and misses the opportunity to uncover the department’s desired patient treatment goals.
The first question you ask Dr. Cardonza should be one that opens the conversation around the departmental and patient treatment goals that Dr. Cardonza is trying to achieve.
The best question is, “From previous conversations with Dr. Gomez, I’ve learned that you want to continue building your department’s reputation and stay at the forefront of medical advances. Whenever you begin the prescribing process with a consideration of the patient treatment goals, it enhances your ability to advance the prescribing cycle.

pageContent.summary:
This is an Execute Next Steps question, not a Problems question. It focuses too narrowly on the implementation of one initiative instead of on potential areas for value creation.
The best question to ask at this point is, “What other obstacles do you anticipate facing as you focus on achieving your patient treatment goals?”This is a Problems question that probes deeper into the issues Dr. Cardonza faces in his department.
Here is how Dr. Cardonza would have answered that question:
“We have several to consider. First, many of our patients have no or sub-optimal insurance, which can prevent us from pursuing optimal treatment plans. Second, as much as we’d sometimes like to, we can’t force patients to change their lifestyles or be compliant with their treatment plans. Finally, we have limited control over what other physicians in the community, such as primary care, may do; and we have limited control over what other hospitals do. If other cardiology departments make improvements faster and better than we do, we could be bumped from the “top 100” list. But, if it’s all in the name of better patient care, I can’t get too upset about that.”

pageContent.summary:
This is an Execute Next Steps question, but it doesn’t build on the previous conversation. It might advance the conversation to this specific topic, but it’s closed-ended, and it doesn’t engage Dr. Cardonza in partnering with the customer to create value.
The best question to ask at this point is, “What factors or criteria are most important to you when you consider trialing a product you have never used before?”
This Execute Next Steps question moves you toward taking action and helps you to better understand what he values when making prescribing decisions.
Here is how Dr. Cardonza would have answered that question:
